title: 111_s888
content: The "Oil Industry Tax Break Repeal Act of 2009" limits percentage depletion for oil and gas wells and terminates the treatment of natural gas distribution lines as 15-year property. The Oil Industry Tax Break Repeal Act of 2009 amends the Internal Revenue Code regarding property placed in service, with exceptions for existing contracts or construction. SEC. 103 amends the Internal Revenue Code to terminate temporary expensing for equipment used in refining liquid fuels. The amendments apply to property placed in service on or after the date of the enactment of the Act. SEC. 104 treats natural gas gathering lines as 15-year property. SEC. 104 amends the Internal Revenue Code to classify natural gas gathering lines as 15-year property for tax purposes. The Oil Industry Tax Break Repeal Act of 2009 makes amendments to the Internal Revenue Code regarding property placed in service, with exceptions for properties under binding contracts or already under construction before the enactment date. SEC. 105 terminates the deduction for intangible drilling and development costs for taxable years after the enactment date. SEC. 106 terminates the enhanced oil recovery credit. SEC. 106 terminates the enhanced oil recovery credit for taxable years after the enactment date. SEC. 107 terminates the credit for producing oil and gas from marginal wells. SEC. 108 amends the tax code to exclude Alaska natural gas pipelines from being treated as 7-year property. It applies to property placed in service on or after the enactment of the Oil Industry Tax Break Repeal Act of 2009. SEC. 109 denies deductions for large integrated oil companies related to domestic production of oil, gas, or primary products. The amendment to the tax code excludes Alaska natural gas pipelines from being treated as 7-year property. It also denies deductions for large integrated oil companies related to domestic production of oil, gas, or primary products. Additionally, it defines a "large integrated oil company" as an integrated oil company meeting specific criteria. The amendment to the tax code excludes Alaska natural gas pipelines from being treated as 7-year property and denies deductions for large integrated oil companies with specific criteria. The amendments apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 110. REVALUATION OF LIFO INVENTORIES OF LARGE INTEGRATED OIL COMPANIES. SEC. 110. REVALUATION OF LIFO INVENTORIES OF LARGE INTEGRATED OIL COMPANIES. Notwithstanding any other provision of law, applicable integrated oil companies must increase the value of historic LIFO inventories of petroleum products by a layer adjustment amount and decrease cost of goods sold accordingly. If the increases exceed cost of goods sold, gross income is increased by the excess amount. The term "layer adjustment amount" is defined for this purpose. The term "layer adjustment amount" refers to a calculation involving $18.75 multiplied by the number of barrels of crude oil or barrel-of-oil equivalents in a historic LIFO layer. The term "barrel-of-oil equivalent" is defined separately. Any adjustments required by this section do not constitute a change in accounting method, and underpayments of estimated tax do not incur additional tax penalties. No tax penalties for underpayments of estimated tax related to installment payments for the taxable year described in the section. An "applicable integrated oil company" is defined as having specific production and revenue criteria for the taxable year ending in 2008. For the taxable year ending in 2008, all persons considered a single employer under certain sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 are treated as one entity. MODIFICATIONS OF FOREIGN TAX CREDIT RULES APPLICABLE TO LARGE INTEGRATED OIL COMPANIES WHO ARE DUAL CAPACITY TAXPAYERS. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include special rules for large integrated oil companies that are dual capacity taxpayers. Any amount paid to a foreign country or possession of the United States by such companies will not be considered a tax under certain conditions. The Internal Revenue Code includes special rules for large integrated oil companies that are dual capacity taxpayers. Any excess amount paid to a foreign country or possession of the United States by such companies will not be considered a tax under certain conditions. Dual capacity taxpayer is defined as a taxpayer subject to both the generally applicable income tax and a specific tax imposed by the country or possession. In tax law, a dual capacity taxpayer is someone subject to a levy of a foreign country or possession, who also receives a specific economic benefit from that country or possession. Generally applicable income tax refers to income taxes imposed by a foreign country on income derived from business activities within that country. The term 'large integrated oil company' is defined as an integrated oil company with gross receipts exceeding $1,000,000,000 and an average daily worldwide production of at least 500,000 barrels of crude oil. The amendments made by this section apply to taxes paid or accrued in taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act, except where contrary to any treaty obligation of the United States. SEC. 112 terminates the deduction for tertiary injectants for taxable years after the enactment date. TITLE II establishes the ENERGY TRUST FUND and dedicates resulting revenues to it. The Energy Trust Fund is established in the Treasury of the United States to accelerate the use of clean domestic renewable energy resources, promote energy-efficient products and practices, and increase research and development in the energy sector. The Energy Trust Fund aims to boost clean renewable energy research, development, and deployment. The Energy Trust Fund, established under Sec. 9511, supports clean renewable energy research, development, and deployment.
